bibl.title: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, April 5, 1948

div1.p: Lyons is surprised and pleased at the large number of photostats of Reed material that Hench has sent to the Hall of Fame. She discusses the use of the material and gives Hench directions to the Hall of Fame, where he will attend a ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, April 5, 1948
div1.p:
Every American is a shareholder in the Hall of Fame
HALL OF FAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY
I MADISON AVENUE · NEW YORK IO, N. Y.
Telephone: MURRAY HILL 3-4469
5 April 1948 Dear Dr. Hench:

Your registered air mail letter of April 1
with all of the photostats arrived this morning, and I must
confess that when I opened the envelope and saw the amount of
material that you had gone to the trouble to assemble for me,
I had considerable pangs of conscience. However, after read-
ing the last sentence in your first paragraph, I am selfish
enough to believe that I have done you a good turn insofar
as having made it possible for you to have your data under
one roof. But, in all seriousness, I am very much indebted
to you and scarcely know how to thank you for all of your
trouble.

I have just had time enough to go through the
material and mark each piece on the back, and to read your
letter with its valuable suggestions. First of all, let me put
your mind at ease as to the reproduction of any personal material
relating to the Reeds contained in the letters of Walter Reed
to his wife. We shall certainly not make use of anything but
information which would give the lay person an idea of how Reed
went along with his experiments, and perhaps some of his enthusiasm
when he found himself on the road to success. I agree with you
fully that one is entitled to privacy and we shall not invade it.

I have not had the time yet to compare the photo-
stats with your recommendations of items to be reproduced in our
program. I want to go over them all very carefully with Dr. Angell
and get his reactions to some of these things. Really, there is
so much of interest and so little space in our program, that I
think we are going to find it rather difficult to make the choices
and have the reproductions of interest to all concerned. But,
we will do the best we can. Of that you may be sure.

In reproducing the birthplace, we plan to put this
note under it:
The birthplace of Reed, Belroyi, Gloucester County, Virginia.
This modest cabin (purchased and dedicated by the
Virginia State Medical Society) was occupied by
Walter Reed's parents as a temporary refuge during
the time their parsonage (which had been badly damaged
by fire) was being rebuilt.
We submitted this to General Reed and he has given us his approval
of it. Don't you think that it covers it pretty well?

I note what you say with regard to returning the
material to you after it has served our purpose, and in the instances
where our printer does not have to cut the photostat for deletion, etc.
we shall certainly return everything to you.

I am delighted that you now plan to attend the ceremony.
I communicated with the La Guardia Airport and learned from them that
you should allow at least an hour after you get out of your plane and to
come to New York. The limousine from the airport will land you at
42nd Street and it will take you an additional forty-five minutes to
go to the Heights where the ceremony will be held. If you can let
me know about four days in advance of May 20 when you expect to arrive
at 42nd Street in New York, perhaps I can arrange to send one of our
cars for you. We are planning to send our participants in the pro-
gram up to the University in special cars, and I could leave room
in one car for you. But as I said, I would have to know at least
four days in advance in order that I could route my cars properly.
I understand that the trip from the Newark Airport to 42nd Street
entails about the same amount of time, so that you would have to
count on an hour and three-quarters, at least, after leaving the
ceremony at University Heights.

There will be a Procession before the Exercises
start and those participating in the Procession (as I hope you will)
will assemble in the library of the University at the Heights
no later than 2:15 D. S. T. The Procession will get under way
precisely at 2:30 and the Exercises in the auditorium, where the
ceremony, will be held, will commence promptly at 3 o'clock. The
program should take one hour and fifteen minutes only, provided
the speakers adhere to the time schedule which we have allotted for
them, which would make the hour 4:15 or 4:30. After that there
will be a Tea in the Faculty Club which we hope that you and
Mrs. Hench can also attend. That, however, will have to be something
which you must decide depending entirely upon your plane schedule.
I understand that we go on Daylight Saving Time here in New York
on the 25th of April.

With every good wish to you, and with renewed
appreciation of everything that you have done for us, believe
me,

Sincerely yours,
Bertha L. Lyons
Assistant to the Director
BLL:YZ
P. S. Do please tell me how much we owe you for the
photostats!!
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
